ccre.ctrl

Class ExpirationTimer

  • java.lang.Object
    • ccre.ctrl.ExpirationTimer

  • public final class ExpirationTimer
extends java.lang.Object
    An ExpirationTimer acts sort of like an alarm clock. You can schedule a series of alarms with certain delays, and then start the timer. When each delay passes, the timer will trigger the event associated with the delay. The timer can be fed, which restarts the timer (can be used to implement WatchDogs, hence the name). The timer can also be stopped, which resets the timer and prevents it from running until it is started again.
    Author:
    skeggsc

      • scheduleSet

        public void scheduleSet(long delay,
               BooleanOutput out,
               boolean value)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Schedule a BooleanOutput to be set to a specified value at a specific delay.
        Parameters:
        delay - the delay (in milliseconds) to trigger at.
        out - the BooleanOutput to modify.
        value - the value to modify it to.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer is already running.

      • scheduleBooleanPeriod

        public void scheduleBooleanPeriod(long start,
                         long stop,
                         BooleanOutput out,
                         boolean setToDuring)
                           throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Schedule a BooleanOutput to be set to a specific value during the specified range of times, and then set to the inversion of the value afterwards.
        Parameters:
        start - the beginning of the period.
        stop - the end of the period.
        out - the BooleanOutput to modify.
        setToDuring - the value to set to during the period.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer is already running.

      • scheduleToggleSequence

        public void scheduleToggleSequence(BooleanOutput control,
                          boolean beginWith,
                          long beginAt,
                          long... additionalToggles)
                            throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Schedule a BooleanOutput to go through a series of changes over the course of the timer's execution. The output will be set to the specified boolean at the start, and then toggled at each specified time after that.
        Parameters:
        control - the BooleanOutput to modify.
        beginWith - the boolean to begin with.
        beginAt - when to begin.
        additionalToggles - when each subsequent toggle should occur. (each element should be larger than the previous, but this is not checked.)
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer is already running.

        cnsm - the event to fire.

      • startOrFeed

        public void startOrFeed()
        Start or restart the timer running.

      • feed

        public void feed()
          throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Reset the timer. This will act as if the timer had just been started, in terms of which events are fired when.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer was not started.

      • stop

        public void stop()
          throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Stop the timer. This will prevent the timer from running until start is called again.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the timer was not started.

      • getStartEvent

        public EventOutput getStartEvent()
        Get an event that, when fired, will start the timer. This will not throw an IllegalStateException if the timer is already running.
        Returns:
        the event to start the timer.

      • getStartOrFeedEvent

        public EventOutput getStartOrFeedEvent()
        Get an event that, when fired, will start or feed the timer, like startOrFeed().

        the event to start or feed the timer.

        See Also:
        getStopEvent()

      • getRunningControl

        public BooleanOutput getRunningControl()
        Get a BooleanOutput that can be written to in order to control whether or not this timer is running. This will start or stop the timer when the outputted value changes. This will not throw an IllegalStateException if the timer is in the wrong state or log a warning.
        Returns:
        a BooleanOutput to control the ExpirationTimer.

      • getRunningStatus

        public BooleanInputPoll getRunningStatus()
        Get a BooleanInputPoll representing whether or not the timer is running.
        Returns:
        an input representing if the timer is running.

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Check if the timer is running.
        Returns:
        if the timer is running.
